abstract: In its debut season, "Boardwalk Empire" was nominated for 18 Emmy Awards and won eight, including a trophy for the direction of its pilot episode, which was handled by Martin Scorsese.
snippet: In its debut season, "Boardwalk Empire" was nominated for 18 Emmy Awards and won eight, including a trophy for the direction of its pilot episode, which was handled by Martin Scorsese.
lead_paragraph: The saga of organized crime in America didn't end in 1921, and "Boardwalk Empire" won't conclude then, either. On Wednesday, HBO announced it had renewed "Boardwalk Empire," its period drama about mobsters, corrupt public officials and one particularly short-tempered federal agent in Prohibition-era Atlantic City, for a third season. The series, which is created by Terence Winter (a producer of "The Sopranos") and adapted from Nelson Johnson's book of the same title, was nominated for 18 Emmy Awards in its debut season, including nods for dramatic series and for the lead actor, Steve Buscemi, who plays the bootlegger and political powerbroker Nucky Thompson; among the eight Emmys it picked up was an award for the direction of its pilot episode, handled by Martin Scorsese, an up-and-comer we think you're going to be hearing a lot about. "Boardwalk Empire" is believed to be one of the costliest series that HBO has produced, with a reported budget of $18 million for its pilot episode alone.

headline.main: HBO Orders Third Season of 'Boardwalk Empire'
